# Draft:Battle of Cabo de São Vicente

The Battle of Cape St. Vincent, fought on July 5, 1833, was a decisive naval encounter in the Portuguese Civil War. The naval force commanded by British officer Charles John Napier, serving as regent for Queen Maria II, defeated the royalist armada of King Miguel, commanded by Admiral António Torres de Aboim. The encounter took place off Cape St. Vincent, resulting in a decisive victory for the liberal forces. With this battle, the absolutist armada virtually disappeared.

Description
In the summer of 1833, the Liberal government decided to send a naval force to the coasts of Alentejo and Algarve with the aim of landing forces there that would allow it to open a new front in the civil war, advancing on Lisbon from the south. The Royalist government responded by sending its loyal squadron to the southern coast, under the command of squadron commander António Torres de Aboim. The Royalist force consisted of two ships, two frigates, three corvettes, and two brigs.
The enemy forces sighted each other on July 3rd, but only after two days of maneuvers, on the morning of the 5th of that month, did the battle break out, off Cape St. Vincent. The hesitation at the beginning of the battle was unfavorable to the Miguelist squadron, as in the meantime a calming of the wind and sea had occurred, allowing the Liberal squadron, commanded by Charles Napier, to launch a bold attack on the enemy ships. By resorting to hand-to-hand combat, avoiding the traditional artillery clash with line maneuvers, he managed to nullify the Miguelists' numerical and firepower advantage.
The commander of the Miguelist forces, bound by conventional combat tactics better mastered by the Portuguese officers, was surprised by the audacity of Napier, a British naval officer with much greater tactical flexibility. This engagement, which can be seen as a battle between the British and the Portuguese, as the commanders of the force's main ships, in addition to the admiral of the Liberal squadron, were also British, resulted in the capture of the Miguelist squadron's ships, frigates, and a corvette. The disaster was enormous, with only the corvettes Isabel Maria and Cíbele escaping, retreating to Lisbon. The brig Tejo sought refuge on Madeira, and the brig Audaz surrendered in Lagos the following day. With this battle, the armada loyal to D. Miguel practically disappeared, leaving the Liberals with full control of the sea.
